title-group.article-title: Influence of inorganic fillers on the fire protection of intumescent coatings

article-meta.aff: 1Unité Matériaux et Transformations (UMET), UMR-CNRS 8207, Equipe Ingénierie des Systèmes Polymères, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Lille (ENSCL), Villeneuve d’Ascq Cedex, France
2Rockwool B.V., Lapinus Fibres, Roermond, The Netherlands

author-notes.corresp: Sophie Duquesne, Unité Matériaux et Transformations (UMET), UMR-CNRS 8207, Equipe Ingénierie des Systèmes Polymères, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Lille (ENSCL), BP 90108, 59652 Villeneuve d’Ascq Cedex, France. Email: sophie.duquesne@ensc-lille.fr

abstract.p: Intumescent coatings, mainly composed of ammonium polyphosphate, pentaerythritol and melamine, are widely used in the field of fire protection of steel structures. The objective of this study was to investigate how the presence of two different inorganic fillers (titanium dioxide and mineral fibres) will affect the fire performance of an acrylic-based intumescent coating. In both cases, it was observed that the inorganic filler enabled improvement of the fire-protective behaviour of intumescent paints, maintaining their performance for a longer time. The mode of action was attributed to reinforcement of the char due to the presence of the fillers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Passive fire protection materials insulate steel structures from the effects of the high temperatures that can be generated in fire. They can be divided into two types, non-reactive, of which the most common types are boards and sprays, and reactive, of which intumescent coatings are the best example.

Intumescent coatings provide an appearance similar to that of a paint finish, and remain stable at ambient temperatures. However, in a fire situation, the increase in temperature causes a chemical reaction and the intumescent coating expands to many times its original thickness. This provides an insulating foam-like coating or ‘char’ that protects the substrate for a certain period of time.1,3

The intumescent coating is designed to insulate the steel and prevent its temperature from rising above a certain point, called the failure temperature (550°C is usually taken as the failure temperature of steel in cellulosic fires). The aim of the intumescent coatings is thus to extend as much as possible the time taken by the steel to reach this temperature.

The intumescence process is caused by the interaction of three components: a carbon source (polyols such as pentaerythritol), an acid source (such as ammonium polyphosphate (APP)) and a blowing agent (such as melamine). The above components are bound in a solvent- or water-borne polymeric binder. Other components can be added to improve the paint properties and to enable easy application or to achieve faster drying.4

Moreover, in most of the cases, inorganic fillers such as titanium dioxide (TiO2) or inorganic fibres are added to the formulation for various reasons. It has been demonstrated that APP is very reactive and can react with most of those inorganic fillers leading to thermally stable phosphates.5
–12

The objective of this study was thus to investigate how the presence of those fillers affects the properties of the intumescent protective char. In the first part, the use of inorganic fibres is investigated and in the second part, the use of TiO2 is investigated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Raw materials were resins (Emultex DP 5457 from Synthomer for the polyvinyl acetate (PVA1-based systems or Mowilith DM230 from Celanese for PVA2-based systems) and intumescent additives (APP: Exolit AP422 supplied by Clariant, melamine (MEL) and pentaerythritol (PER) or dipentaerythritol (diPER) purchased from Aldrich and used as received without any further purification). The mineral fillers have been supplied by Lapinus (trade name Rockforce® MS603-Roxul®1000) for the mineral fibres (MFs) and by Huntsman for the TiO2 (trade name TR92). Rockforce MS603-Roxul®1000 is a high quality engineered MF. Its chemical composition and physical properties are reported in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. In Europe, Tioxide® TR92 pigment is the most widely used TiO2 pigment. Its physical properties are reported in Table 3. Chlorinated paraffin (Cereclor 70) was used in PVA2-based systems.

caption.p: Chemical analysis of Rockforce® MS603-Roxul®1000
Physical properties of Rockforce® MS603-Roxul®1000
Physical properties of Tioxide® TR92

sec.title: Formulations
sec.p: The formulations based on PVA were prepared by mixing first the melamine, the PER or diPER (previously dispersed in water), the fibres and the resin using a deflocculated steel stir shaft. Then, APP was added and homogeneously dispersed with a spatula.

Tables 4 and 5 report the formulations used to prepare the intumescent coatings. Each coating will be referenced as PVA1-name-x% or PVA2-name-ratio Ti/P depending, respectively, on the mineral filler used and on its content (as an example PVA1-MS603-2% corresponds to the intumescent paint prepared with 2% of MF using the PVA1 resin (Emultex DP 5457) and PVA2-TiO2-0.5 corresponds to the intumescent paint prepared with a atomic ratio between titanium and phosphorus equal to 0.5) and with PVA2 resin (Mowilith DM230).

caption.p: PVA1-based intumescent formulations
PVA2-based intumescent formulations

sec.title: Cone calorimeter test
sec.p: Temperature profiles were measured on coated steel plate (coated place exposed to the heat source) for a sample exposed to a constant heat flux of 35 or 50 kW/m2 under the conditions of the cone calorimeter as presented in Figure 1.

caption.p: Experimental set-up of temperature profile measurements under the cone calorimeter conditions.

sec.p: Temperatures were measured versus time every 3 s using Thermocoax (Suresnes, France) K-type thermocouples with the junction diameter of 0.5 mm. The thermocouples were fastened at two different heights (x = 0 cm and 1 cm) from the interface between the coating and the steel plate as shown in Figure 2. Initially, the thermocouples located 1 cm above the interface are surrounded by the atmosphere, but as the coating expands, the thermocouples get surrounded by the intumescent structure and, consequently, the temperature changes in the interior layers of the coating could be measured.

caption.p: Schematic representation of the experimental set-up of temperature profile measurements versus time and distance under the cone calorimeter conditions.

sec.title: Epiradiator test
sec.p: The epiradiator test is a small-scale test developed in our laboratory in order to evaluate fire performance of intumescent coatings (Figure 3).

caption.p: Experimental set-up of temperature profiles measurements under the epiradiator test.

sec.p: The heat source is a radiator provided by Saint Gobain (France). The steel plates used are squares of 10 cm × 10 cm with a thickness of 5 mm. About 600 µm of dried intumescent coating is applied on the surface of the steel plate. A black coating, provided by Medtherm Corp. (Huntsville, AL), resistant to 800°C and having a constant emissivity of 0.92, is applied on the non-heated side of the steel plates. The constant emissivity of the backside of the plate allows accurate measurement of its surface temperature using an infrared pyrometer. The infrared pyrometer is positioned at a constant distance from the steel plate, and the beam is pointed on the centre of the plate. It detects the temperature on the non-heated face of the steel plate and registers the time/temperature curve on a computer. This test is used for comparison of the temperature profiles versus time. This small-scale test is very stable and repeatable. The whole system is placed into a box in order to avoid the effect of the fume cupboard reducing the convective and chimney effects.

sec.title: Electron probe microanalyser
sec.p: A Cameca SX100 electron probe microanalyser (EPMA) was used to perform elemental analysis. The samples were embedded into an epoxy resin, polished and carbon-coated with a Bal-Tec SCD005 sputter coater. Back-scattered electron images were carried out at 10 kV, 15 nA, full spectra for the detection of elements were carried out at 10 kV, 15 nA and X-ray mappings were carried out at 10 kV, 40 nA. For mappings, the crystals used to detect the Ka of the C, Ca and P were, respectively, a Ni/C multilayer cristal (PC2), Penta-erythritol (PET) and Thallium Acid Phthalate (TAP).

sec.title: X-ray diffraction analysis
sec.p: The X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were recorded in the (3°–60°) 2θ angle range using a Brucker AXS D8 diffractometer with radiation Cu Kα(λ(Cu Kα) = 1.5418 Å) in configuration 2θ/θ. The acquisition parameters were as follows: a step of 0.02° and a step time of 2 s. The data are analysed using the diffraction patterns of Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD). The ICSD is a comprehensive collection of crystal structure entries for inorganic materials, produced by Fachinformationszentrum Karlsruhe, Germany, and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, USA. The ICSD includes records of all inorganic crystal structures with atomic coordinates published since 1913. The database contains more than 70,000 records.

sec.title: Thermal analyses
sec.p: The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out at 10°C/min under synthetic air (flow rate: 50 mL/min; Air Liquide grade) using a Setaram MTB 10-8 microbalance. In each case, the mass of the sample used was fixed at 10 mg and the samples (powder mixtures) were positioned in open vitreous silica pans. The precision of the temperature measurements was 1.5°C over the whole range of temperatures.

sec.title: The use of MFs in intumescent paints
Temperature profiles obtained in cone calorimeter
sec.p: The temperature profiles obtained in a cone calorimeter experiment at the interface between the coating and the substrate (Figure 4(a)) and at x = 1 cm (Figure 4(b)) are presented for the reference formulation (PVA1-ref) and for PVA1-MS603-2% in Figure 4.

caption.p: Temperature profiles obtained for PVA1-MS603-2% and PVA1-ref in the cone calorimeter conditions (50 kW/m2) at the (a) interface and at (b) x = 1 cm.

sec.p: The temperature profiles obtained at the interface show two parts: a first one where the temperature sharply increases until it reaches around 200°C and a second one where the temperature slowly increases up to around 300°C after 1800 s. During the first part, the intumescence develops to form a sufficiently high amount of char to protect the substrate leading to a slope break of the temperature profile. During the second step, the intumescent char is efficient enough to protect the material and the increase in temperature is relatively low.

Those results demonstrate that the temperature reached at the interface for the intumescent formulation containing the MFs is lower than the one obtained for the reference formulation. It thus demonstrates that the use of MFs in the intumescent coating enables improvement of its efficiency.

At 1 cm above the interface, the temperature profiles are different. At t < 100–110 s, the temperature increases very rapidly and a peak is observed. During this step, the thermocouple is in the air; so measurement is not accurate and as a consequence, the data obtained during this step cannot be discussed. When the intumescent shield covers the thermocouple (t > 110 s), the temperature increases slowly, similarly to the one obtained for the temperature measured at the interface. It is observed that the temperature reached for the reference formulation is lower when compared to the one for the coating including MFs. This can be explained by the fact that the use of fibres leads to a decrease in the expansion of the coatings (Figure 5) and thus, the amount of protective layer between the thermocouple and the heat source is lower and the temperature is higher.

caption.p: Pictures of the residue obtained after cone calorimeter test (50 kW/m2) for the PVA1-reference (a) and for the PVA1-MS603-2% (b).

sec.p: Similar experiments have been carried out including 5% of fibres and the temperature profile measured at the interface is presented in Figure 6. Similarly to what observed for the formulation containing 2%, the use of fibres enables obtaining a better protection since the temperature measured at the interface between the coating and the substrate is lower for PVA1-MS603-5% compared to the reference during the whole of the experiment. Moreover, at t = 1400 s, a variation of the slope of the temperature curves is observed for the coating without fibres and thus, the temperature of the reference formulation increases faster. This effect could be attributed to the collapse of the intumescent char structure. It may thus be assumed that the use of fibres maintains the char integrity for a longer period. This effect is particularly important since the aim of intumescent coatings is to delay as much as possible the time for which the structural steel reaches its failure temperature.

caption.p: Temperature profiles obtained at the interface between the coating and the substrate for PVA1-MS603-5% compared with the reference in the cone calorimeter conditions (50 kW/m2).

sec.title: Heat radiator test
sec.p: In order to validate the positive effect of fibres when incorporated in intumescent coatings, the fire performance of PVA1-MS603 containing 5% of fibres has been evaluated using the heat radiator test. The temperature profiles obtained for the non-coated substrate, for the PVA-based formulation without fibres and with 5% of MS603 are presented in Figure 7.

caption.p: Temperature profiles obtained at the back face of the substrate for PVA1-ref and PVA1-MS603-5% during the epiradiator test.

sec.p: The temperature profiles are similar to those obtained by cone calorimetry. That is to say that the curves can be divided into two steps, namely, a step corresponding to the development of the intumescent process where the temperature sharply increases up to around 210°C and then a second step where the intumescent shield plays its protective role and thus, where the temperature reaches a pseudo-steady state. When comparing the systems with and without fibres, it is clear that the fibres enable maintaining the char integrity for longer. Indeed, whereas for PVA1-MS603-5%, the temperature is stable up to 4000 s (>1 h), the temperature on the backside of the PVA1-ref coated sample increases slowly between 1000 and 3600 s (at around 1°C/min) and then more rapidly (at around 3°C/min) up to 4000 s corresponding to the destruction of the protective layer.

The fire-protective behaviour of PVA-based intumescent paints with and without fibres has been investigated. It was demonstrated that better performance, in particular at long protection time, can be achieved using fibres in intumescent coating presumably because the fibres allow the char integrity to be maintained for longer.

sec.title: Char morphology
sec.p: The char morphology analysis has been performed on the PVA-MS603-5% formulation in order to better understand the mode of action of the fibres.

First, the virgin paint was analysed before heat treatment. The scanning electron microscopic (SEM) picture (back-scattered electron (BSE) image) of the formulation is presented in Figure 8. A ‘brighter’ BSE intensity correlates with greater average atomic number (Z) in the sample, and ‘dark’ areas have lower average Z. The fibres are observable on the pictures (bright grey) and their size is in the range of the data given in the datasheet of the fibre (Table 2 - 125 ± 25 µm). Moreover, an analysis has been carried out using wavelength dispersive spectroscopy (WDS) probe (not presented in this article) and confirms in the bright grey part the presence of Si, Al, Mg, Ca, K and O.

caption.p: BSE picture of PVA-MS603-5%.
BSE: back-scattered electron.

sec.p: The intermediate grey part corresponds to the APP that is included in the formulation at high loading. It is also possible to observe that between the APP particles, some resin is present and enables maintaining the integrity of the paint. Finally, the larger dark grey regions are attributed to the presence of melamine.

Small pieces of paint (1 cm × 1 cm) were exposed to the heat radiator test and samples have been collected just after ignition (t1) and after 30 min (t2). In each case, the char layer exhibits a big bubble in the centre (Figure 9(a)). In order to perform the analysis, the char has been cut in its centre (black part in Figure 9(b)). The top and the bottom of the sample have then been analysed separately.

caption.p: Schematic representation of the char analysed using microprobe (a) after exposition to heat radiator and (b) cut in the resin for analysis.

sec.p: The results are reported in Figures 10 to 13. Compositional maps have been obtained for three elements: carbon, calcium and phosphorus. White regions correspond to a region rich in the considered element whereas it is the opposite for black regions. Silicon was not selected for the analysis of the fibre since prior to the analysis, the sample was polished and the polishing product contains silicon; so, a contamination could not be excluded.

caption.p: Compositional maps (C, Ca and P) of the bottom of the char residue of PVA-MS603-5% at t1 (analysis carried out on 2 mm × 2 mm region).
Compositional maps (C, Ca and P) of the top of the char residue of PVA-MS603-5% at t1 (analysis carried out on 1 mm × 2 mm region).
Compositional maps (C, Ca and P) of the bottom of the char residue of PVA-MS603-5% at t2 (analysis carried out on 2 mm × 2 mm region).
Compositional maps (C, Ca and P) of the top of the char residue of PVA-MS603-5% at t2 (analysis carried out on 2 mm × 2 mm region).

sec.p: First of all, it appears that the char residue is mainly composed of phosphorus and carbon. The compositional maps corresponding to C present some black regions that do not correspond either to phosphorus-rich regions or to calcium-rich regions. These black regions of the C compositional maps are more or less spherical and could thus be attributed to open cells (no material). When comparing the analysis performed at t1, it can be noticed that the number of the cells is higher when the bottom is analysed. Thus, the porosity of the intumescent char is not homogeneous through the thickness of the char and the bottom of the char presents a higher porosity. This phenomenon has already been reported in the literature.13

A gradient in the fibre content through the char can also be observed particularly at t2. Indeed, almost no Ca is detected at the bottom of the materials when a large region is analysed whereas when the top is analysed, Ca-rich regions can be observed. Ca is detected in regions where neither carbon nor phosphorus is detected. Thus, it can be assumed that those regions correspond to the presence of fibres. As a consequence, it can be reasonably assumed that the top of the char is richer in fibre content compared with the bottom. Moreover, the shape of the fibres is not maintained since more or less spherical Ca-rich regions are observed. So, modification of the fibres (such as its crystallinity) or its reaction with other component of the formulation (such as APP or its degradation products) during the heat treatment can be assumed.

Finally, it can be observed that regarding phosphorus compositional maps, in the char collected at the top of the sample (Figures 11 and 13), some regions presenting a high amount of phosphorus are observed. Formation of calcium phosphate could be excluded since no correlation between Ca and P compositional maps are observed.

The fire-protective behaviour of PVA-based intumescent paints with and without fibres has been investigated. It is demonstrated that better performance, in particular over a long time period, can be achieved using fibres in intumescent coatings, presumably because fibres allow the char integrity to be maintained. It was also observed that the use of fibres limits the expansion, particularly when high loadings are used.

The analysis of the compositional maps of char demonstrates that a gradient in fibre content is observed (higher concentration on the top). Moreover, it also demonstrated that the fibres react and/or degrade, since their shape is not maintained after heat treatment.

sec.title: The use of TiO2 in intumescent coatings
Influence of TiO2 on fire-protective behaviour
sec.p: TiO2 is widely used in intumescent paints for various purposes. In particular, it is used traditionally as white pigment in intumescent-coating compositions providing colour to the coating. Its reactivity with APP leading to the formation of titanium pyrophosphate (TiP2O7) is reported in the literature.7,14 However, its effect regarding flame retardancy is controversial. Some papers conclude a beneficial contribution of the interaction between APP and TiO2 7 while others do not report any benefit.14

Figure 14 reports the temperature profiles obtained at the interface between the coating and the substrate in cone calorimeter conditions (35 kW/m2). Similar to that is observed in the case of the formulation including MFs, the temperature profiles can be divided into two parts. The temperature sharply increases for t < 150 s and then increases slowly. The first part corresponds to the development of the intumescent shield. When the protective shield is formed, the increase in temperature is slower and thus, the intumescent shield is efficient. Moreover, similar to the results obtained in the case of MFs, the temperature at the steady state is lower when the formulation includes TiO2. As a consequence, a beneficial effect of TiO2 is demonstrated on the fire-protective behaviour of the intumescent paint.

caption.p: Temperature profiles obtained at the interface between the coating and the substrate for PVA2-ref and PVA2-TiO2-0.5 in the cone calorimeter conditions (35 kW/m2).

sec.title: Influence of the ratio APP/TiO2
sec.p: Figure 15 reports the temperature profiles obtained at the interface between the coating and the substrate in cone calorimeter conditions (35 kW/m2) for various titanium/phosphorus ratios. It is observed that the better performance is obtained for a atomic ratio between titanium and phosphorus equal to 0.5, corresponding to the ratio observed in TiP2O7. It is thus possible to assume that the use of TiO2 improves the fire-protective behaviour of intumescent paints since TiO2 can react with APP, or with its degradation products, to form a ceramic-like layer of TiP2O7 at high temperature.15 It should however be noted that even if the ratio between the ingredients (APP/melamine/diPER) in the three formulations is maintained, the mineral content for high Ti/P ratio is higher, affecting the char structure and thus its properties. So even if a role of TiP2O7 in the fire protection of intumescent coatings was suspected, other parameters (such as, e.g. char expansion) have also to be taken into account.

caption.p: Temperature profiles obtained at the interface between the coating and the substrate for PVA2-TiO2 prepared with different Ti/P ratio in the cone calorimeter conditions (35 kW/m2).

sec.title: XRD analysis of the char residue
sec.p: The XRD curve of the residue obtained after the cone calorimeter experiment of the formulation PVA2-TiO2-0.5 is presented in Figure 16 (core of the sample) and in Figure 17 (top of the surface). Several peaks are observed at 2θ equal to 36.2 and 54.4 and were assigned to TiO2, whereas those at 22.8 and 25.4 were attributed to TiP2O7. It demonstrates that part of the inorganic filler has reacted with APP and/or its degradation products to form TiP2O7. Moreover, it is observed that the intensity of the TiO2 peaks on the diffractogram of the residue collected at the surface is lower, demonstrating that, similar to that observed for the MFs in the previous section, a gradient of concentration in TiP2O7 should occur in the charring residue.

caption.p: XRD diffractogram of the residue obtained after the cone calorimeter experiment of the formulation PVA2-TiO2-0.5 (core of the sample).
XRD: X-ray diffraction.
XRD diffractogram of the residue obtained after the cone calorimeter experiment of the formulation PVA2-TiO2-0.5 (surface of the sample).
XRD: X-ray diffraction.

sec.title: Thermal stability of APP/TiO2 mixture
sec.p: In order to go further in the understanding of the mode of action of TiO2 in intumescent paints, the TGA experiments of APP/TiO2 mixtures were carried out for various Ti/P ratio (Figure 18). Whereas TiO2 is relatively stable from ambient temperature to 800°C, APP degrades in two steps. The two degradation steps of APP were previously reported in the literature.16,17 The first step, which begins around 300°C, consists essentially of elimination of NH3 and H2O, leading to the formation of a highly cross-linked polyphosphoric acid, whereas the second step, at a temperature higher than 550°C, corresponds to polyphosphoric acid evaporation and/or dehydration to P4O10 that sublimes. When TiO2 is added to APP at a Ti/P ratio = 0.5 (corresponding to a weight ratio TiO2/APP around 20/80), the second step of degradation of the APP is sharply reduced. This second step disappears for higher Ti/P ratio. It is thus reasonable to assume that TiO2 reacts with APP or with its degradation products leading to the formation of thermally stable species, mainly TiP2O7. Those species could help to maintain the char integrity for a longer time and thus is beneficial to the fire retardant properties of the coatings.

caption.p: TGA curves of different mixtures between APP and TiO2 (under air, 10°C/min).
TGA: thermogravimetric analyses; APP: ammonium polyphosphate.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Intumescent coatings are widely used as passive fire-protection materials to insulate steel structures. Whereas the basic ingredients of intumescent paints are composed of an acid source (such as APP), a carbon source (such as for example pentaerythritol or its dimer) and a blowing agent (such as for example melamine), inorganic fillers are usually added for various purposes. This study investigates the influence of two types of inorganic filler (MFs and TiO2) on the fire-protective behaviour of an intumescent coating. In both cases, the fire protection is improved when the fillers are added to the coating. Since APP is very reactive, it is suspected that at high temperature, the inorganic filler reacts with APP or with its degradation products leading to the formation of thermally stable phosphate species (such as TiP2O7 in the case of TiO2). It may thus reasonably be assumed that those species enable the char to maintain its integrity and thus, the protection lasts for a longer time compared to pure systems without inorganic fillers.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors would like to thank Eureka (Project INCOAT, Development of Innovative intumescent coatings) and Lapinus Fibers for their financial supports and for helpful discussion.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Sophie Duquesne got her PhD from collaboration between the University of Lille (France) and the University of Torino (Italy) in 2001. She then joined the Ecole Nationale de Chimie de Lille (ENSCL, Villeneuve d’Ascq, France) as lecturer and since 2009, got a position of professor. Her research interests concern the processing of flame-retarded materials such as thermoplastics, elastomers and textiles as well as the development of fire-protective coating. In particular, she investigates the intumescent process developing physical and chemical approaches for a better understanding of this phenomenon.

Pierre Bachelet got his Master’s degree in 2009 in Industrial Chemistry and Process Engineering at the ‘Conservatoire National des Arts et Métiers’ of Lille. He joined the Ecole Nationale de Chimie de Lille (ENSCL) in 2004 as engineer assistant to work on the elaboration of bio-based nanocomposites through reactive extrusion. His research field deals with the development of intumescent thermoplastics materials and thermoset coatings. He is also working on the development of novel small-scale test methods to evaluate the reaction and resistance to fire of materials.

Séverine Bellayer got her PhD in Macromolecular Chemistry in 2005 from a collaboration between NIST and the Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Arts et Industries Textiles (ENSAIT, Roubaix, France). Since 2006, she works at Ecole Nationale de Chimie de Lille (ENSCL, Villeneuve d’Ascq, France) as a research engineer in microscopy and microanalysis. She works in the field of the characterization of polymeric material from the nano to the micron scale in order to correlate their nano/micro-structure to their macroscopic properties.

Serge Bourbigot got his PhD in 1993 and he joined ENSCL as an assistant professor in 1993. He passed his French ‘Habilitation à Diriger des Recherches’ in chemical engineering at the University of Lille in 1998. He got a position of associate professor in chemical engineering at ENSAIT in 1999. In 2002, Prof. Bourbigot left his laboratory to go to NIST (Gaithersburg, MD, USA) in sabbatical leave for a year. In 2003, ENSCL offered him a position of full professor in flame retardancy. His research interest includes reaction and resistance to fire of polymeric materials such as thermoplastics, thermosets, textiles and coating with special emphasis on solid-state NMR and modelling.

William Mertens, born in 1979, received his master degree in chemical engineering in 2002, major Coating Technology. After a brief period at Chemshop BV (now Cambridge Major Laboratories) in Weert, he worked for 4 years as a research chemist at Stahl International in Waalwijk, mainly in the field of synthesis and application of water-borne polyurethane systems. Since July 2007, he works for Rockwool B.V. in Roermond within the department of Lapinus Fibres. In his position as a development manager, he is responsible for the application development activities towards the added value of MFs in paint and coating applications.
